tasks.task: Collecting and Preparing Soil Samples for Testing
subtasks: Divide property into management zones
Collect 10-15 core samples across each garden area, avoiding problem spots
Use clean tools, remove roots, and lay samples to dry
Verify lab certification (North American Proficiency Testing Program) and choose a lab (e.g., Colorado State University Extension, Midwest Laboratories)
Follow lab-specific sampling and shipping instructions
Send 2 cups of thoroughly mixed soil in a clean container
Review pH, EC, organic matter, nutrient levels (N, P, K, Ca, Mg, S, micronutrients)
Interpret soil texture (sand, silt, clay) using simple at-home methods
Consider biological factors (e.g., earthworms, crop health) and physical conditions (erosion, compaction)
Adjust soil amendments and fertilizers based on test results and local recommendations
Refer to extension bulletins (OSU, CSU) for detailed interpretation and utilization advice
Monitor and balance macronutrients (N, P, K) and micronutrients (Ca, Mg, S, Fe, Zn, Mn, Cu, B)
Address pH management, usinglime or sulfur to adjust soil acidity
Manage soil salinity through mulching, drainage, and selecting salt-tolerant plants
Reduce leaching of nitrate and control excess salts
Apply fertilizers and amendments as needed, following lab recommendations and gradual incorporation
Apply organic amendments (compost, manure, cover crops) to improve soil structure and fertility
Incorporate Earthworms and other microorganisms for healthy soil biology
Practice no-till or minimum-till techniques to maintain soil structure and organic matter
Monitor and manage water infiltration and drainage to prevent soil erosion and sodium accumulation
Select crops suitable for local soil conditions, considering pH tolerance and nutrient availability
